trailingComments.value: Get a list of available providers for use in your templates.

leadingComments.value: Get a list of available providers for use in your templates.

* * Render the login page * * The login form itself is just a simple HTML form: *
* * You could optionally add CSRF-protection as outlined in the documentation: * http://sailsjs.org/#!documentation/config.csrf * * A simple example of automatically listing all available providers in a * Handlebars template would look like this: * {{#each providers}} {{name}} {{/each}} * * @param {Object} req * @param {Object} res

trailingComments.value: mark the user as logged out for auth purposes

leadingComments.value: mark the user as logged out for auth purposes

*
   * Log out a user and return them to the homepage
   *
   * Passport exposes a logout() function on req (also aliased as logOut()) that
   * can be called from any route handler which needs to terminate a login
   * session. Invoking logout() will remove the req.user property and clear the
   * login session (if any).
   *
   * For more information on logging out users in Passport.js, check out:
   * http://passportjs.org/guide/logout/
   *
   * @param {Object} req
   * @param {Object} res

*
   * Render the registration page
   *
   * Just like the login form, the registration form is just simple HTML:
   *
      <form role="form" action="/auth/local/register" method="post">
        <input type="text" name="username" placeholder="Username">
        <input type="text" name="email" placeholder="Email">
        <input type="password" name="password" placeholder="Password">
        <button type="submit">Sign up</button>
      </form>
   *
   * @param {Object} req
   * @param {Object} res

*
   * Create a third-party authentication endpoint
   *
   * @param {Object} req
   * @param {Object} res
Only certain error messages are returned via req.flash('error', someError)
because we shouldn't expose internal authorization errors to the user.
We do return a generic error and the original request body.

trailingComments.value: If an error was thrown, redirect the user to the
login, register or disconnect action initiator view.
These views should take care of rendering the error messages.

leadingComments.value: If an error was thrown, redirect the user to the
login, register or disconnect action initiator view.
These views should take care of rendering the error messages.

trailingComments.value: Mark the session as authenticated to work with default Sails sessionAuth.js policy

leadingComments.value: Mark the session as authenticated to work with default Sails sessionAuth.js policy

trailingComments.value: Upon successful login, send the user to the homepage were req.user

leadingComments.value: Upon successful login, send the user to the homepage were req.user

*
   * Create a authentication callback endpoint
   *
   * This endpoint handles everything related to creating and verifying Pass-
   * ports and users, both locally and from third-aprty providers.
   *
   * Passport exposes a login() function on req (also aliased as logIn()) that
   * can be used to establish a login session. When the login operation
   * completes, user will be assigned to req.user.
   *
   * For more information on logging in users in Passport.js, check out:
   * http://passportjs.org/guide/login/
   *
   * @param {Object} req
   * @param {Object} res

*
   * Disconnect a passport from a user
   *
   * @param {Object} req
   * @param {Object} res

*
 * Authentication Controller
 *
 * This is merely meant as an example of how your Authentication controller
 * should look. It currently includes the minimum amount of functionality for
 * the basics of Passport.js to work.

comments.value:
*
 * Authentication Controller

* * Render the login page * * The login form itself is just a simple HTML form: *

Get a list of available providers for use in your templates.

*
   * Log out a user and return them to the homepage
   *
   * Passport exposes a logout() function on req (also aliased as logOut()) that
   * can be called from any route handler which needs to terminate a login
   * session. Invoking logout() will remove the req.user property and clear the
   * login session (if any).
   *
   * For more information on logging out users in Passport.js, check out:
   * http://passportjs.org/guide/logout/
   *
   * @param {Object} req
   * @param {Object} res

*
   * Render the registration page

   * Just like the login form, the registration form is just simple HTML:
   *
      <form role="form" action="/auth/local/register" method="post">
        <input type="text" name="username" placeholder="Username">
        <input type="text" name="email" placeholder="Email">
        <input type="password" name="password" placeholder="Password">
        <button type="submit">Sign up</button>
      </form>

   * @param {Object} req

*
   * Create a authentication callback endpoint
   *
   * This endpoint handles everything related to creating and verifying Pass-
   * ports and users, both locally and from third-aprty providers.
   *
   * Passport exposes a login() function on req (also aliased as logIn()) that
   * can be used to establish a login session. When the login operation
   * completes, user will be assigned to req.user.
   *
   * For more information on logging in users in Passport.js, check out:

Only certain error messages are returned via req.flash('error', someError)
because we shouldn't expose internal authorization errors to the user.
We do return a generic error and the original request body.
If an error was thrown, redirect the user to the
login, register or disconnect action initiator view.
These views should take care of rendering the error messages.
Mark the session as authenticated to work with default Sails sessionAuth.js policy
